channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Biden says no American will be left behind
item.description: The US president says the chaos in Afghanistan was unavoidable and refuses to acknowledge any mistakes.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: 'Many here will be deeply fearful for their future'
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports from the heart of Kabul during the unfolding crisis in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Pakistan fences off from Afghan refugees
item.description: Islamabad says it cannot accept any more Afghans fleeing Taliban rule, despite UN pleas.

item.title: The villages cut off from help by Haiti earthquake
item.description: The tremor razed their homes, but these survivors could still die for a lack of basic supplies.

item.title: R. Kelly trial: Singer 'knew I was underage', accuser tells court
item.description: The US R&B singer is accused of sexual abuse, racketeering and bribery; charges which he has denied.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: First Covid case detected at Paralympic village
item.description: Japan is battling a record wave of coronavirus infections just five days before the start of the Games.

item.title: Former Netflix staffers charged for making $3m from insider trading
item.description: The Wall Street regulator says confidential subscriber growth data was used in the alleged scheme.

item.title: Lithuania says Belarus officers illegally pushed migrants over border
item.description: Video shows 12 Belarusian officers in riot gear as migrants scramble towards Lithuanian territory.

item.title: Apple censors engraving service, report claims
item.description: Apple restricts the engraving of political phrases in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, a report alleges.

item.title: IMF suspends Afghanistan's access to funds
item.description: The move follows the Taliban's takeover, and lack of global agreement over who now governs Afghanistan.

item.title: Israel extends Covid restrictions to three-year-olds as cases surge
item.description: Young children must show proof of a negative test to enter many indoor spaces, as infections surge.

item.title: Aspirin may help treat aggressive breast cancer
item.description: Doctors hope it could boost the anti-cancer power of other drugs to fight hard-to-treat tumours.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Algeria: The forest fires that led to an artist's lynching
item.description: When Djamel Ben Ismail went to fight forest fires in Algeria, his life was cut short by a raging mob.

item.title: Tigray crisis: Ethiopian teenagers become pawns in propaganda war
item.description: The BBC is told they were forced to fight for Tigray's rebels, but were words put into their mouths?

item.title: Brazil hopes the world will get a taste for its favourite spirit
item.description: With domestic sales of cachaÃ§a falling last year, Brazilian producers want to export more.

item.title: The little-known human stories behind emoji designs
item.description: The surprising story of how some tiny characters ended up on billions of smartphone keyboards.

item.title: How latte art in South Africa led to a job from hell in Oman
item.description: A South African barista was offered a dream opportunity in Oman but unknowingly signed away his freedoms.

item.title: Uncertain times ahead for Afghan women
item.description: After the Taliban takeover, it is not yet clear how women will fare with the militants in power.

item.title: Taliban victory will test India, and peace in South Asia
item.description: How India engages with the Taliban after Afhraf Ghani left Afghanistan could determine the region's fate.

item.title: Biden's speech on Afghanistan fact-checked
item.description: How consistent was President Biden's speech with his previous statements on Afghanistan?

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Hakainde Hichilema: The Zambian 'cattle boy' who became president
item.description: After six attempts, Hakainde Hichilema has finally become president of Zambia.

item.title: Can the Paralympics bring lasting change?
item.description: A campaign gets underway to try to improve the lives of the world's 1.2bn disabled people.

item.title: Afghanistan: Fatalities as shots fired at flag protest in Jalalabad
item.description: Protesters took to the streets of Jalalabad holding aloft the country's national flag.

item.title: Taliban have been looking for me, says ex-Afghanistan bank governor
item.description: Militants have been knocking on the doors of places he used to live, Ajmal Ahmady says.

item.title: How technology in the air battles fires on the ground
item.description: Planes equipped with infrared scanners are helping authorities take on historic wildfires in the US.

item.title: Brandon Flowers on new Killers album Pressure Machine, inspired by Utah hometown
item.description: The Killers frontman speaks about their new album, Pressure Machine, inspired by his rural hometown.

item.title: 'It was very emotional on the plane out of Afghanistan'
item.description: Afghan businesswoman Hassina Syed speaks of her relief at getting out on a British military plane.

item.title: Veteran silences MPs with powerful Afghan speech
item.description: Tory MP Tom Tugendhat speaks of the anger, grief and rage of veterans at the "abandonment" of Afghanistan.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani: Afghanistan's exiled president lands in UAE
item.description: The UAE says it has welcomed the president and his family on humanitarian grounds.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's the impact of Taliban's return on international order?
item.description: What is the diplomatic fallout and how allies and rivals are looking at the US following the Taliban takeover?

item.title: Afghanistan: Joe Biden said chaos was 'inevitable'
item.description: In an interview with ABC, Joe Biden said nobody could have anticipated the speed of the Taliban takeover.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'All female staff have left my Kabul hotel'
item.description: The BBC's Malik Mudassir says Taliban fighters are now providing security at his hotel in central Kabul.
